content: When someone requests changes on my PR in github, and I push new commits that I believe address those concerns, am I expected to hit the "resolve conversation" button? I've been doing so in an attempt to indicate that I believe the concern to be addressed, but am now worrying that this may be a bit of a faux pas and it is actually expected that the person requesting the changes be allowed to make the decision of whether or not to mark as resolved

I've been doing both. Largely marking them myself for nits and other minutiae which has an obvious solution and I'm pretty sure I've resolved. I leave it unresolved and maybe add a comment if the topic is non-trivial for any reason.
I often review PRs later for context on stuff so I often leave things "unresolved" in the UI sense because I want to be able to see them... but only if they matter, so yeah, same. Nits I just close.

nagisa said:

I've been doing both. Largely marking them myself for nits and other minutiae which has an obvious solution and I'm pretty sure I've resolved. I leave it unresolved and maybe add a comment if the topic is non-trivial for any reason.

Likewise. If someone reports something highly subjective, and I haven't already had a comment exchange with them to ask if something would work, then I'll push something and ask them. But if something seems like a largely objective request and I've addressed it, I'll mark it resolved. It can always be un-resolved if they disagree.
And that helps with using it as a todo list.
interesting to see how others deal with this, I'm going to reconsider what I do :)
I often just mark things as resolved as soon as I think are resolved, expecting that the reviewer will check things again and judge if more iterations are needed or if it's good to go
i feel it's better to leave it to the reviewer to mark it as resolved
I'm firmly in the "PR author does the resolving" camp :smile:
I resolve conversation if I feel I've addressed their concerns. They then re-review and can open additional comments if necessary
Imo it depends on multiple factors. How trivial is the feedback and fix? Is the diff outdated after refactoring? Was it the reviewer who made the comment?

nnethercote said:

I'm firmly in the "PR author does the resolving" camp :)

In principle I agree with this, and similarly that issue submitters should confirm that a change fixes their issue. But in practice, it seems to scale better to go ahead and resolve things, because resolving something is trivially reversible.
